fields.name: Lower Great Range
fields.description: A hike beginning at the Ausable Club that features five high peaks and a waterfall.

fields.name: Dial, Nippletop, Colvin, and Blake
fields.description: Four mountains that can be reached from the Adirondack Mountain Reserve, making for a long day.

fields.name: Ridge Trail to Giant and Rocky Peak
fields.description: A steep ascent to two high peaks that offer some of the best views. But did I get a view on this overcast day?

fields.name: Haystack / Basin / Saddleback
fields.description: Habasa is a favorite for many, featuring three mountains with terrific views and the often dreaded Saddleback cliffs.

fields.name: Cascade and Porter
fields.description: Two of most frequented high peaks, due to the fact that the hike is on the shorter side, and the views from Cascade are fantastic.

fields.name: Slide, Cornell, Wittenberg, Panther Loop
fields.description: Instead of doing Slide, Cornell, and Wittenberg in a single hike, why not add Panther and a loop for a very full day.

fields.name: Devil's Path
fields.description: Notoriously difficult hike in the Northeast, especially when adding Hunter and SW Hunter to the mix.

fields.name: Blackhead, Black Dome, and Thomas Cole
fields.description: A mini loop that passes over 3 of the highest mountains in the Catskills.

fields.name: Windham via Elm Ridge Trail
fields.description: A relatively short hike to the summit of one of the Catskill's popular ski resorts.

fields.name: Rusk from Sprucetown Rd.
fields.description: A very short hike featuring a herd path, that can also be done as a loop.

fields.name: Halcott Mountain
fields.description: A short loop with Halcott Mountain sandwiched in the middle.

fields.name: Phelps
fields.description: For my 46er finish, Phelps was my lone mountain remaining. Maybe the weather was not the greatest, but I still felt very appreciative to have come so far.

fields.name: Pemi Loop
fields.description: An extremely long and strenuous loop with extensive time on ridge lines, and added complexity due to potentially unavailable water sources.

fields.name: Whiteface and Esther
fields.description: Sure you can drive up Whiteface to get the terrific views of Lake Placid, but then you would miss out on a classic in Esther.

fields.name: Big Slide via the Brothers
fields.description: A relatively short hike featuring great views almost the entire way makes this hike a favorite.

fields.name: Seward Range
fields.description: Hiking all four mountains of the Seward Range in one day is often the longest hike undertaken by an aspiring 46er.

fields.name: Dix Range
fields.description: A natural grouping of five mountains, featuring herd trails and beautiful views of Elk Lake.

fields.name: Street and Nye
fields.description: Nearby the Adirondack Loj and a short hike, but Street and Nye are notorious due to a stream crossing, mud, and herd paths.

fields.name: MacIntyre Range Loop
fields.description: Instead of doing the out and back of Wright, Algonquin, and Iroquois, I was looking for a longer and more original day.

fields.name: Allen
fields.description: A hike that is hated by many due to its length and the lack of camping options in the vicinity. So was I crazy to be looking forward to Allen?

fields.name: Santanoni Range
fields.description: When thinking about the Santanoni Range, you can't help but think about lots of mud and that long slog to Couch.

fields.name: Cliff and Redfield
fields.description: No matter how you slice it, Cliff and Redfield are very deep into the wilderness, so you really have to get in there if you want to pay a visit.

fields.name: Colden from Avalanche Pass
fields.description: Avalanche Pass is a must-see for any Aspiring 46er, and this also features the Colden ladders or steps, as well as the beautiful Mount Colden.

fields.name: Gray, Skylight, Marcy, and Tabletop
fields.description: Gray, Skylight, and Marcy is a classic, especially with the opportunity to do a loop, and even better was taking the time to add one more.
